title: Reading Notes: 'Specialization and Trade'
contents:
Book Info
“Specialization and Trade: A Re-introduction to Economics”
by Arnold Kling
Thesis
The economy is best viewed as a set of patterns of sustainable specialization and trade (PSST).
Specialization should replace scarcity and choice as the most fundamental aspect of economics.

“The work you do probably does not produce something you could consume. Even more striking is the fact that almost everything you consume is something you could not produce.”

Specialized, roundabout production in modern economies implies:
strong interdependence among firms and
financial intermediation embedded in nearly every business.
Economics Models as Interpretative Frameworks
Economic models are best viewed as interpretive frameworks; they do not make falsifiable predictions. Causal density and evolution make model assumptions hard to validate and predictions very context dependent.
The Inadequate Metaphor of the Machine
The predominate view treats the economy as a machine that can be engineered using the mathematics of constrained optimization and the psychology of Behaviorism.
A better metaphor is a computer network.
Characterized by emergent behavior
“Software” (i.e., individual and collective knowledge) is at least as important as “hardware”
Unemployment as an Adjustment Problem
Unemployment can be viewed as a combination of static and dynamic adjustment problems.
Static: Mismatching and mispricing with a given job structure
Dynamic: Entrepreneurs must discover new patterns of specialization and trade by trial and error
In the PSST framework, the dynamic adjustment problem is the more significant. It is beyond the reach of the metaphor of the machine and has evolutionary characteristics. Permanent job losses are only remedied by discovering new PSST and creating jobs that do not yet exist.
Understanding the Subsidize Demand/Restrict Supply Pattern
The “subsidize demand/restrict supply” prescription for perceived market failures is inconsistent with conventional theories of market failure but common in public policy.
Specialization implies individual productivity strongly depends on how its combined with other tasks/inputs. Individual well-being is much more greatly affected by the market for what one produces rather than the market for the variety of goods one consumes. Therefore, concentrated interests more naturally form on the supply side of markets.
Thus, the “subsidize demand/restrict supply” pattern in public policy follows easily from a PSST/public choice framework.
Fluctuations as Reputational Minsky Cycles
Specialized, roundabout production implies that financial intermediation is embedded in nearly all industries/firms. Financial intermediaries also perform risk transformation. To be useful, they are necessarily opaque—reputations must matter in finance.
Fluctuations can be understood as reputational Minsky cycles of the financial industry.
Hedge Phase: Following downturn, reputations are low. This induces conservative behavior, and reputations begin to improve.
Speculative Phase: Investment increases. More risky but mostly sound projects are financed. Losses can be covered by gains or obscured. Reputations continue to improve.
Ponzie Phase: Reputations are undeservedly high. Increasing levels of investment lead to increasingly unsound projects being financed. Losses accumulate and begin to reach savers. Reputations collapse.

title: Reading Notes: 'The Three Languages of Politics'
contents:
Book Info
“The Three Languages of Politics: Talking Accross the Political Divides”
by Arnold Kling (3rd Edition)
Thesis
Political languages evolved in context of tribal gamesmanship. The languages enable political communication in a manner that effectively signals to our own political tribes; not being understood by other tribes is a feature and not a bug.
A three-axis model is posited that describes the predominate paradigm that frames each tribe’s political communications.
Progressive Axis: Oppressor <—> Oppressed
Conservative Axis: Civilization <—> Barbarism
Libertarian Axis: Liberty <—> Coercion
Quick Guide to the Groups
Group
Believe in
Revere
View markets as
Progressives
Human betterment
Science
Unfair
Conservatives
Human weakness
The past
Virtuous
Libertarians
Human rationality
Technology
Peaceful cooperation
Why It Matters
Family, enduring friendship, meaningful shared work, and local communities are declining. Political tribalism is expanding to fill the resulting void.
Motivated reasoning occurs instinctively and at an unconscious level. Open-minded reasoning requires effort and an ability to understand other political languages; such fluency allows disagreement without conflict.
On Reasonable Disagreement
Good-faith disagreements can occur between coherent, reasonable points of view. Rather than questioning the reasonability of an opposing view, a better question may be whether its application is appropriate for the circumstances.
Heuristic:

“The only person you are qualified to pronounce unreasonable is yourself.”
